sp.p: A cold world Curtis in euery office but thine, and therefore fire: doe thy dutie, and haue thy dutie, for my Master and mistris are allmost frozen to death.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: There's fire readie, and therefore good Grumio the newes.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why Iacke boy, ho boy, and as much newes as thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Come, you are so full of conicatching.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Why therefore fire, for I haue caught extreme cold. Where's the Cooke, is supper readie, the house trim'd, rushes
strew'd, cobwebs swept, the seruingmen in their new fustion, the white stockings, and euery officer his wedding garment on? Be the Iackes faire within, ●he Gils faire without, the Carpets laide, and euery thing in order?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: All ready: and therefore I pray thee newes.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: First know my horse is tired, my master and mistris falne out.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Out of their saddles into the durt, and thereby hangs a tale.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Let's ha't good Grumio.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Lend thine eare.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Heere.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: This 'tis to feele a tale, not to heare a tale.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: And therefore 'tis cal'd a sensible tale: and this Cufte was but to knocke at your eare, and beseech listning: now I begin Inprimis we came downe a foule hill, my Master riding behinde my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Both of one horse?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Why a horse.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crost me, thou shouldst haue heard how her horse fell, and she vnder her horse: thou shouldst haue heard in how miery a place, how she was bemoil'd, how he left her with the horse vpon her, how he beate me because her horse stumbled, how she waded through the durt to plucke him off me: how he swore, how she prai'd, that neuer prai'd before: how I cried, how the horses ranne away, how her bridle was burst: how I lost my crupper, with many thinges of worthy memorie, which now shall die in obliuion, and thou returne vnexperienc'd to the graue.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: By this reckning he more shrew than she.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: I, and that thou and the proudest of you all shall finde when he comes home. But what talke I of this? Call forth Nathaniell, Ioseph, Nicholas, Phillip, Walter, Sugersop and the rest: let their heads bee slickely comb'd, their blew coats brush'd, and their garters of an indifferent knit, let them curtsie with their left legges, and not presume to touch a haire of my Masters horse-taile till they kisse their hands. Are they all readie?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: They are.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Call them forth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Doe you heare ho? you must meete my maister to countenance my mistris.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why she hath a face of her owne.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Who knowes not that?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Thou it seemes, that calls for company to countenance her.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I call them forth to credit her.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why she comes to borrow nothing of them.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Welcome home Grumio.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How now Grumio.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: What Grumio.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: Fellow Grumio.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: How now old lad,

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Welcome you: how now you: what you: fellow you: and thus much for greeting. Now my spruce companions, is all readie, and all things neate?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: All things is readie, how neere is our master?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: E'ne at hand, alighted by this: and therefore be not—
Cockes passion, silence, I heere my master.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where be these knaues? what no man at doore
To hold my stirrop, nor to take my horse?
Where is Nathaniell, Gregory, Phillip.

sp.speaker: All ser.
sp.l: Heere, heere sir, heere sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Heere sir, heere sir, heere sir, heere sir.
You logger-headed and vnpollisht groomes:
What? no attendants? no regard? no dutie?
Where is the foolish knaue I sent before?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Heere sir, as foolish as I was before.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You pezant, swaine, you horson malt-horse drudg
Did I not bid thee meete me in the Parke,
And bring along these rascall knaues with thee?

sp.speaker: Grumio.
sp.l: Nathaniels coat sir was not fully made,
And Gabriels pumpes, were all vnpinkt i'th heele:
There was no Linke to colour Peters hat,
And Walters dagger was not come from sheathing:
There were none fine, but Adam, Rafe, and Gregorie,
The rest were ragged, old, and beggerly,
Yet as they are, heere are they come to meete you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Go rascals, go, and fetch my supper in. Ex. Ser.
Where is the life that late I led?
Where are those? Sit downe Kate,
And welcome. Soud, soud, soud, soud.
Why when I say? Nay good sweete Kate be merrie.
Off with my boots, you rogues: you villaines, when?

l.hi: It was the Friar of Orders gray,
As he forth walked on his way.

sp.l: Out you rogue, you plucke my foot awrie,
Take that, and mend the plucking of the other
Be merrie Kate: Some water heere: what hoa.
Where's my Spaniel Troilus? Sirra, get you hence,
And bid my cozen Ferdinand come hither:
One Kate that you must kisse, and be acquainted with.
Where are my Slippers? shall I haue some water?
Come Kate and wash, and welcome heartily:
You horson villaine, will you let it fall?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Patience I pray you, 'twas a fault vnwilling.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A horson beetle-headed flap-ear'd knaue:
Come Kate sit downe, I know you haue a stomack,
Will you giue thankes, sweete Kate, or else shall I?
What's this, Mutton?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis burnt, and so is all the meat
What dogges are these? Where is the rascall Cooke?
How durst you villaines bring it from the dresser
And serue it thus to me that loue it not?
There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all:
You heedlesse iolt-heads and vnmanner'd slaues.
What, do you grumble? Ile be with you straight.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I pray you husband be not so disquiet,
The meat was well, if you were so contented.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I tell thee Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away,
And I expressesly am forbid to touch it:
For it engenders choller, planteth anger,
And better 'twere that both of vs did fast,
Since of our selues, our selues are chollericke,
Then feede it with such ouer-rosted flesh:
Be patient, to morrow 't shall be mended,
And for this night we'l fast for companie.
Come I will bring thee to thy Bridall chamber. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Peter didst euer see the like.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: He kills her in her owne humor.

sp.speaker: Grumio.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: In her chamber, making a sermon of continencie to her, and railes, and sweares, and rates, that she (poore soule) knowes not which way to stand, to looke, to speake, and sits as one new risen from a dreame. Away, away, for he is comming hither.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Thus haue I politickely begun my reigne,
And 'tis my hope to end successefully:
My Faulcon now is sharpe, and passing emptie,
And till shee stoope, she must not be full gorg'd,
For then she neuer lookes vpon her lure,
Another way I haue to man my Haggard,
To make her come, and know her keepers call:
That is, to watch her, as we watch these Kites,
That baite, and beate, and will not be obedient:
She eate no meate to day, nor none shall eate.
Last night she slept not, nor to night she shall not:
As with the meat, some vndeserued fault
Ile finde about the making of the bed,
And heere Ile fling the pillow, there the boulster,
This way the Couerlet, another way the sheetes:
I, and amid this hurly I intend,
That all is done in reuerend care of her,
And in conclusion, she shall watch all night,
And if she chance to nod, Ile raile and brawle,
And with the clamour keepe her still awake:
This is a way to kill a Wife with kindnesse,
And thus Ile curbe her mad and headstrong humor:
He that knowes better how to tame a shrew,
Now let him speake, 'tis charitie to shew. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Is't possible friend Lisio, that Mistris Bianca
Doth fancie any other but Lucentio,
I tell you sir, she beares me faire in hand,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, to satisfie you in what I haue said,
Stand by, and marke the manner of his teaching.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Now Mistris profit you in what you read?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: What Master reade you first, resolue me that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I read, that I professe the Art to loue.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: And may you proue sir Master of your Art.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: While you sweete deere proue Mistresse of my heart.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Quicke proceeders marry, now tell me I pray,
You that durst sweare that your mistris Bianca
Lou'd me in the world so well as Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Oh despightfull Loue, vnconstant womankind,
I tell thee Lisio this is wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mistake no more, I am not Lisio,
Nor a Musitian as I seeme to bee,
But one that scorne to liue in this disguise,
For such a one as leaues a Gentleman,
And makes a God of such a Cullion;
Know sir, that I am call'd Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Signior Hortensio, I haue often heard
Of your intire affection to Bianca,
And since mine eyes are witnesse of her lightnesse,
I will with you, if you be so contented,
Forsweare Bianca, and her loue for euer.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: See how they kisse and court: Signior, Lucentio,
Heere is my hand, and heere I firmly vow
Neuer to woo her more, but do forsweare her
As one vnworthy all the former fauors
That I haue fondly flatter'd them withall.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And heere I take the like vnfained oath,
Neuer to marrie with her, though she would intreate,
Fie on her, see how beastly she doth court him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Would all the world but he had quite forsworne
For me, that I may surely keepe mine oath.
I will be married to a wealthy Widdow,
Ere three dayes passe, which hath as long lou'd me,
As I haue lou'd this proud disdainfull Haggard,
And so farewell signior Lucentio,
Kindnesse in women, not their beauteous lookes
Shall win my loue, and so I take my leaue,
In resolution, as I swore before.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Mistris Bianca, blesse you with such grace,
As longeth to a Louers blessed case:
Nay I haue tane you napping gentle Loue,
And haue forsworne you with Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Tranio you iest, but haue you both forsworne me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Mistris we haue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then we are rid of Lisio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I'faith hee'l haue a lustie Widdow now,
That shall be woo'd, and wedded in a day.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: God giue him ioy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I, and hee'l tame her.

sp.speaker: Bianca.
sp.l: He sayes so Tranio

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Faith he is gon vnto the taming schoole.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: The taming schoole: what is there such a place?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I mistris, and Petruchio is the master,
That teacheth trickes eleuen and twentie long,
To tame a shrew, and charme her chattering tongue.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Oh Master master I haue watcht so long,
That I am dogge wearie, but at last I spied
An antient Angell comming downe the hill,
Will serue the turne

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What is he Biondello?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Master a Marcantant, or a pedant,
I know not what, but formall in apparell,
In gate and countenance surely like a Father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And what of him Tranio?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: If he be credulous, and trust my tale,
Ile make him glad to seeme Vincentio,
And giue assurance to Baptista Minola,
As if he were the right Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Take me your loue, and then let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: God saue you sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And you sir, you are welcome,
Trauaile you farre on or are you at the farthest?

sp.speaker: Ped:
sp.l: Sir at the farthest for a weeke or two,
But then vp farther, and as farre as Rome,
And so to Tripolie, if God lend me life,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What Countreyman I pray?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Of Mantua.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Of Mantua Sir, marrie God forbid,
And come to Padua carelesse of your life.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: My life sir? how I pray? for that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis death for any one in Mantua
To come to Padua, know you not the cause?
Your ships are staid at Venice, and the Duke
For priuate quarrell 'twixt your Duke and him,
Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly:
'Tis maruaile, but that you are but newly come,
You might haue heard it else proclaim'd about.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Alas sir, it is worse for me then so,
For I haue bills for monie by exchange
From Florence and must heere deliuer them.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well sir, to doe you courtesie,
This will I doe, and this I will aduise you.
First tell me, haue you euer beene at Pisa?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I sir, in Pisa haue I often bin,
Pisa renowned for graue Citizens.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Among them know you one Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know him not, but I haue heard of him:
A Merchant of incomparable wealth.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: He is my father sir, and sooth to say,
In count'nance somewhat doth resemble you.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: As much as an apple doth an oyster, and all one,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: To saue your life in this extremitie,
This fauor will I doe you for his sake,
And thinke it not the worst of all your fortunes,
That you are like to Sir Vincentio.
His name and credit shall you vndertake,
And in my house you shall be friendly lodg'd,
Looke that you take vpon you as you should,
You vnderstand me sir: so shall you stay
Till you haue done your businesse in the Citie:
If this be court'sie sir, accept of it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Oh sir I doe, and will repute you euer
The patron of my life and libertie.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then goe with me, to make the matter good,
This by the way I let you vnderstand,
My father is heere look'd for euerie day,
To passe assurance of a dowre in marriage
'Twixt me, and one Baptistas daughter heere:
In all these circumstances Ile instruct you,
Goe with me to cloath you as becomes you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: No, no forsooth I dare not for my life.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: The more my wrong, the more his spite appeares.
What, did he marrie me to famish me?
Beggers that come vnto my fathers doore,
Vpon intreatie haue a present almes,
If not, elsewhere they meete with charitie:
But I, who neuer knew how to intreate,
Nor neuer needed that I should intreate,
Am staru'd for meate, giddie for lacke of sleepe:
With oathes kept waking, and with brawling fed,
And that which spights me more then all these wants,
He does it vnder name of perfect loue:
As who should say if I should sleepe or eate,
'Twere deadly sicknesse, or else present death.
I prethee goe, and get me some repast,
I care not what, so it be wholsome foode.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: What say you to a Neats foote?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: 'Tis passing good, I prethee let me haue it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I feare it is too chollericke a meate,
How say you to a fat Tripe finely broyl'd?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I like it well, good Grumio fetch it me.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I feare 'tis chollericke.
What say you to a peece of Beefe and Mustard?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: A dish that I do loue to feede vpon.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I but the Mustard is too hot a little.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why then the Beefe, and let the Mustard rest.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Nay then I will not, you shall haue the Mustard
Or else you get no Beefe of Grumio.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Then both or one, or any thing thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why then the Mustard without the beefe.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Go get thee gone, thou false deluding slaue,
That feed'st me with the verie name of meate.
Sorrow on thee, and all the packe of you
That triumph thus vpon my miserie:
Go get thee gone I say.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, and Hortensio with meate.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How fares my Kate, what sweeting all a-mort?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mistris, what cheere?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Faith as cold as can be.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Plucke vp thy spirits, looke cheerefully vpon me.
Heere Loue, thou seest how diligent I am,
To dresse thy meate my selfe, and bring it thee.
I am sure sweet Kate this kindnesse merits thankes.
What, not a word? Nay then thou lou'st it not:
And all my paines is sorted to no proofe.
Heere take away this dish.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I pray you let it stand.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The poorest seruice is repaide with thankes,
And so shall mine before you touch the meate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Signior Petruchio, fie you are to blame:
Come Mistris Kate, Ile beare you companie.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Eate it vp all Hortensio, if thou louest mee:
Much good do it vnto thy gentle heart:
Kate eate apace; and now my honie Loue,
Will we returne vnto thy Fathers house,
And reuell it as brauely as the best,
With silken coats and caps, and golden Rings,
With ruffes and Cuffes, and Fardingales, and thinges:
With Scarfes, and fannes, and double change of brau'ry,
With Amber Bracelets, Beads, and all this knau'ry.
What hast thou din'd? The Tailor stayes thy leasure,
To decke thy bodie with his ruffing treasure,
Come Tailor, let vs see these ornaments
Lay forth the Gowne. What newes with you sir?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Heere is the cap your Worship did bespeake.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why this was moulded on a porrenger,
A Veluet dish: Fie, fie, 'tis lewd and filthy,
Why 'tis a cockle or a wallnut-shell,
A knack, a toy, a tricke, a babies cap:
Away with it come let me haue a bigger.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Ile haue no bigger, this doth fit the time,
And Gentlewomen weare such caps as these.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: When you are gentle, you shall haue one too,
And not till then.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That will not be in hast.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why sir I trust I may haue leaue to speake,
And speake I will. I am no childe, no babe,
Your betters haue indur'd me say my minde
And if you cannot, best you stop your eares,
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
Or else my heart concealing it will breake,
And rather then it shall, I will be free,
Euen to the vttermost as I please in words.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why thou saiest true, it is a paltrie cap.
A custard coffen, a bauble, a silken pie,
I loue thee well in that thou lik'st it not.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Loue me, or loue me not, I like the cap,
And it I will haue, or I will haue none.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Thy gowne why I: come Tailor let vs see't.
Oh mercie God, what masking stuffe is heere?
Whats this? a sleeue? 'tis like a demi-cannon,
What, vp and downe caru'd like an apple Tart?
Heers snip, and nip, and cut, and slish and slash,
Like to a Censor in a barbers shoppe:
Why what a deuils name a Tailor cal'st thou this?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I see shees like to haue neither cap nor gowne.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: You bid me make it orderlie and well,
According to the fashion, and the time.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Marrie and did: but if you be remembred,
I did not bid you marre it to the time.
Goe hop me ouer euery kennell home,
For you shall hop without my custome sir:
Ile none of it; hence, make your best of it.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I neuer saw a better fashion'd gowne,
More queint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:
Belike you meane to make a puppet of me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why true, he meanes to make a puppet of thee.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: She saies your Worship meanes to make a puppet of her

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Oh monstrous arrogance:
Then lyest, thou thred, thou thimble,
Thou yard three quarters, halfe yard, quarter, naile,
Thou Flea, thou Nit, thou winter cricket thou:
Brau'd in mine owne house with a skeine of thred:
Away thou Ragge, thou quantitie, thou remnant,
Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard,
As thou shalt thinke on prating whil'st thou liu'st:
I tell thee I, that thou hast marr'd her gowne.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: Your worship is deceiu'd, the gowne is made
Iust as my master had direction:
Grumio gaue order how it should be done.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I gaue him no order, I gaue him the stuffe.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: But how did you desire it should be made?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Marrie sir with needle and thred.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: But did you not request to haue it cut?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Thou hast fac'd many things.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: I haue.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Face not mee: thou hast brau'd many men, braue not me; I will neither bee fac'd nor brau'd. I say vnto thee, I bid thy
Master cut out the gowne, but I did not bid him cut it to peeces; Ergo thou liest.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: Why heere is the note of the fashion to testifie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Read it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: The note lies in's throate if he say I said so.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: Inprimis a loose bodied gowne.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Master, if euer I said loose-bodied gowne, sow me in the Skirts of it, and beate me to death with a bottome of browne thred: I said a gowne.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Proceede.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: With a small compast cape.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I confesse the cape.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: With a trunke sleeue.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I confesse two sleeues.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: The sleeues curiously cut.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I there's the villainie.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Error i'th bill sir, error i'th bill? I commanded the sleeues should be cut out, and sow'd vp againe, and that Ile proue vpon thee, though thy litle finger be armed in a thimble.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: This is true that I say, and I had thee in place where, thou shouldst know it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: I am for thee straight: take thou the bill, giue me thy meate-yard, and spare not me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: God-a-mercy Grumio, then he shall haue no oddes.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well sir in breefe the gowne is not for me.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: You are i'th right sir, 'tis for my mistris.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Go take it vp vnto thy masters vse.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Villaine, not for thy life: Take vp my Mistresse gowne for thy masters vse.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why sir what's your conceit in that?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Oh sir, the conceit is deeper then you thinke for:
Take vp my Mistris gowne to his masters vse.
Oh fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Hortensio, say thou wilt see the Tailor paide.
Go take it hence, be gone, and say no more.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tailor, Ile pay thee for thy gowne to morrow,
Take no vnkindnesse of his hastie words:
Away I say, commend me to thy master. Exit Tail.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well come my Kate, we will vnto your fathers,
Euen in these honest meane habiliments:
Our purses shall be proud, our garments poore:
For 'tis the minde that makes the bodie rich.
And as the Sunne breakes through the darkest clouds,
So honor peereth in the meanest habit.
What is the Iay more precious then the Larke?
Because his feathers are more beautifull
Or is the Adder better then the Eele,
Because his painted Skin contents the eye.
Oh no Kate: neither art thou the worse
For this poore furniture, and meane array.
If thou accountedst it shame, lay it on me,
And therefore frolike, we will hence forthwith,
To feast and sport vs at thy fathers house,
Go call my men, and let vs straight to him,
And bring our horses vnto Long-lane end,
There will we mount, and thither walke on foote,
Let's see, I thinke 'tis now some seuen a clocke,
And well we may come there by dinner time.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I dare assure you sir, 'tis almost two,
And 'twill be supper time ere you come there.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It shall be seuen ere I go to horse:
Looke what I speake, or do, or thinke to doe,
You are still crossing it, sirs let 't alone,
I will not goe to day, and ere I doe,
It shall be what a clock I say it is.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why so this Gallant will command the sunne:

div.stage: Enter Tranio, and the Pedant drest like Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sirs, this is the house, please it you that I call,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I what else, and but I be deceiued,
Signior Baptista may remember me
Neere twentie yeares a goe in Genoa.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Where wee were Lodgers, at the Pegasus,
Tis well, and hold your owne in any case
With such austeritie as longeth to a father.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I warrant you: but sir here comes your boy,
'Twere good he weere school'd.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Feare you not him: sirra Biondello,
Now doe your dutie throughlie I aduise you:
Imagine 'twere the righ Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Tut, feare not me.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: I told him that your father was at Venice,
And that you look't for him this day in Padua.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Th'art a tall fellow, hold thee that to drinke,
Heere comes Baptista: set your countenance sir.

div.stage: Enter Baptista and Lucentio: Pedant booted and bare headed.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Signior Baptista you are happilie met:
Sir, this is the Gentleman I told you of,
I pray you stand good father to me now,
Giue me Bianca for my Patrimony.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Soft son: sir by your leaue, hauing come to Padua
To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a waightie cause
Of loue beteweene your daughter and himselfe:
And for the good report I heare of you,
And for the loue he beareth to your daughter,
And shee to him: to stay him not too long,
I am content in a good fathers care.
To haue him matcht, and if you please to like
No worse then I vpon some agreement
Me shall you finde readie and willing
With one consent to haue her so bestowed:
For curious I cannot be with you
Signior Baptista, of whom I heare so well.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Sir, pardon me in what I haue to say,
Your plainnesse and your shortnesse please me well
Right true it is your son Lucentio here
Doth loue my daughter and she loueth him
Or both dissemble deepely their affections:
And therefore if you say no more then this,
That like a father you will deale with him,
And passe my daughter a sufficient dower,
The match is made and all is done,
Your sonne shall haue my daughter with consent.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I thanke you sir, where then doe you know best
We be affied and such assurance tane,
As shall with either parts agreement stand.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Not in my house Lucentio for you know
Pitchers haue eares, and I haue manie seruants,
Besides old Gremio is harkning still,
And happilie we may be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then at my lodging, and it like you,
There doth my father lie: and there this night
Weele passe the businesse priuately and well:
Send for your daughter by your seruant here,
My boy shall fetch the Scriuener presentlie,
The worst is this that at so slender warning,
You are like to haue a thin and slender pittance.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: It likes me well:
Cambio hie you home and bid Bianca make her readie straight:
And if you will tell what hath hapned,
Lucentios father is arriued in Padua,
And how she's like to be Lucentios wife.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.l: I pray the Gods she may with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: Dallie not with the Gods, but get thee gone.
Signior Baptista shall I leade the way,
Welcome, one messe is like to be your cheere,
Come sir we will better it in Pisa.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I follow you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Cambio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What saist thou Biondello.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.l: You saw my Master winke and laugh vpon you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Biondello, what of that?

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: Faith nothing: but has left me here behinde to expound the meaning or morrall of his signes and tokens.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I pray thee moralize them.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: Then thus: Baptista is safe talking with the deceiuing Father of a deceitfull sonne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And what of him?

sp.speaker: Biond
sp.l: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And then.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: The old Priest at Saint Lukes Church is at your command at all houres.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And what of all this.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: I cannot tell, expect they are busied about a counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her. Cum preuilegio ad Impremendum solem, to th' Church take the Priest, Clarke, and some sufficient honest witnesses:
sp.l: If this bee not that you looke for, I haue no more to say,
But bid Bianca farewell for euer and a day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hear'st thou Biondello.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: I cannot tarrie: I knew a wench married in an afternoone as she went to the Garden for Parseley to stuffe a Rabit, and so may you sir: and so adew sir, my Master hath appointed me to goe to Saint Lukes to bid the Priest be readie to come against you come with your appendix.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I may and will if she be so contented:
She will be pleasd, then wherefore should I doubt:
Hap what hap may, Ile roundly go about her:
It shall go hard if Cambio go without her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come on a Gods name, once more towards our fathers:
Good Lord how bright and goodly shines the Moone.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: The Moone, the Sunne: it is not Moone-light now.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I say it is the Moone that shines so bright.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I know it is the Sunne that shine, so bright.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now by my mothers sonne, and that's my selfe,
It shall be moone, or starre, or what I list,
Or ere I iourney to your Fathers house:
Goe on, and fetch our horses backe againe
Euer more crost and crost nothing but crost,

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Say as he saies, or we shall neuer goe

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Forward I pray, since we haue come so farr,
And be it moone, or Sunne, or what you please:
And if you please to call it a rush Candle:
Henceforth I vowe it shall be so for me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I say it is the Moone.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I know it is the Moone.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay then you lye: it is the blessed Sunne.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Then God be blest, it is the blessed sun,
But sunne it is not, when you say it is not.
And the Moone changes euen as your minde:
What you will haue it nam'd, euen that it is,
And so it shall be so for Katherine.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Petruchio, goe thy wayes, the field is won.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Well, forward, forward thus the bowle should run,
And not vnluckily against the Bias:
But soft: Company is comming here.
Good morrow gentle Mistris, where away:
Tell mee sweete Kate, and tell me truely too,
Hast thou beheld a fresher Gentlewoman:
Such warre of white and red within her cheekes:
What starrs do spangle heauen with such beautie,
As those two eyes become that heauenly face?
Faire louely Maide, once more good day to thee:
Sweete Kate embrace her for her beauties sake.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: A will make the man mad to make the woman of him.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Yong budding Virgin, faire, and fresh, and sweete,
Whether away, or whether is thy aboade?
Happy the parents of so faire a childe;
Happier the man whom fauourable stars
Alots thee for his louely bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why how now Kate, I hope thou art not mad,
This is a man old, wrinckled, faded, withered,
And not a Maiden, as thou saist he is.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Pardon old father my mistaking eyes,
That haue bin so bedazled with the sunne,
That euery thing I look on seemeth greene:
Now I perceiue thou are a reuerent Father:
Pardon I pray thee for my mad mistaking.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Do good old grandsire, and with all make known
Which way thou trauellest if along with vs,
Wee shall be ioyfull of thy company▪

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Faire Sir, and you my merry Mistris,
That with your strange encounter much amasde me:
My name is call'd Vincentio, my dwelling Pisa,
And bound I am to Padua, there to uisite
A sonne of mine, which long I haue not seene.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Lucentio Gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Happily met the happier for thy sonne:
And now by Law, as well as reuerent age,
I may intitle thee my louing Father,
The sister to my wife, this Gentlewoman,
Thy Sonne by this hath married: wonder not,
Nor be not grieued, she is of good esteeme,
Her dowrie wealthie, and of worthie birth;
Beside, so qualified, as may be seeme
The Spouse of any noble Gentlewoman:
Let me imbrace with old Vincentio,
And wander we to see thy honest sonne,
Who will of thy arriuall be full ioyous.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: But is this true, or is it else your pleasure,
Like pleasant trauailors to breake a iest
Vpon the companie you ouertake?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I do assure thee father so it is.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come goe along and see the truth hereof,
For our first merriment hath made thee iealous. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Well Petruchio, this has put me in heart;
Haue to my Widdow, and if she froward,
Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be vntoward. Exit

div.stage: Enter Biondello, Lucentio and Bianca, Gremio is out before.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.l: Softly and swiftly sir, for the Priest is ready.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I flie Biondello; but they may chance to neede thee at home therefore leaue vs. Exit.

sp.speaker: Biond,
sp.l: Nay faith 'Ile see the Church a your backe,
And then come backe to my mistris as soone as I can.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: I maruaile Cambio comes not all this while.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Vincentio, Grumio With attendants.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sir heres the doore, this is Lucentios house,
My Fathers beares more toward the Market-place,
Thither must I and heere I leaue you sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You shall not choose but drinke before you go,
I thinke I shall command your welcome here;
And by all likelihood some cheere is toward. Knock.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.l: They're busie within, you were best knocke lowder.

div.stage: Pedant lookes out of the window.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What's he that knockes as he would beate downe the gate?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Is Signior Lucentio within sir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He's within sir, but not to be spoken withall.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merrie withall.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Keepe your hundred pounds to your selfe, he shall neede none so long as I liue.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Nay, I told you your sonne was beloued in Padua: doe you heare sir, to leaue friuolous circumstances, I pray you tell Signior Lucentio that his Father is come from Pisa, and is heere at the doore to speake with him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thou liest his Father is come from Padua, and here looking out of the window.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Art thou his Father?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I sir so his mother sayes if I may beleeue her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Why how now Gentleman: why this is flat knauerie to take vpon you an other mans name.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p: Lay hands on the villaine, I beleeue a meanes to cozen some bodie in this Citie vnder my countenance.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: I haue seene them in the Church together, God send them good shipping: but who is heere? mine old Master Vincentio: now we are vndone and brought to nothing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Come hither crackhempe.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: I hope I may choose Sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Come hither you rogue, what haue you forgot mee?

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: Forgot you, no sir: I could not forget you, for I neuer saw you before in all my life.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: What, you notorius villaine, didst thou neuer see thy Mistris father, Vincentio;

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: What my worshipfull old master? yet marrie sir see where he lookes out of the window.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Ist so indeede. He beates Biondello.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe, helpe, here's a mad man will murder me.

sp.speaker: Pedan.
sp.l: Help, sonne, helpe Signior Baptista.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prethee, Kate let's stand aside and see the end of this controuersie.

div.stage: Enter Pedant with seruants, Baptista, Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sir what are you that offer to beate my seruant?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: What am I sir: nay what are you sir: oh immortall Gods▪ oh fine villaine, a silken doublet, a veluet hose, a scarlet cloak and a copataine hat: oh I am vndone, I am vndone: while I plaie the good husband at home, my sonne and my seruant spend all at the vniuersitie.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: What is the man lunaticke?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, you seeme a sober ancient Gentleman by your habit but your words shew you a mad man: why sir, what cernes it you, if I weare Pearle and gold: I thanke my good father, I am able to maintaine it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Thy father: oh villaine, he is a Saile-maker in Bergamo.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: You Mistake sir, you mistake sir, praie what do you think is his name?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: His name, as if I knew not his name: I haue brought him vp euer since he was three yeeres old, and his name is Tronio.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Awaie, away mad asse, his name is Lucentio, and he is mine onelie sonne and heire to the lands of me signior Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Lucentio, oh he hath murdred his Master; lay hold on him I charge you in the Dukes name: oh my sonne, my sonne: tell me thou villaine, where is my sonne Lucentio?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Call forth an officer: Carrie this mad knaue to the Iaile: Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forth comming.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Carrie mee to the Iaile?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Staie officer, he shall not go to prison.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Talke not signior Gremio: I say he shall goe to prison.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Take heede signior Baptista, lest you be conicatcht in this businesse: I dare sweare this is the right Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sweare if thou dar'st,

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Naie, I dare not sweare it.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Yes I know thee to be signior Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Away with the dotard, to the Iaile with him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Thus strangers may be haild and abusd: oh monstrous villaine.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Oh we are spoil'd, and yonder he is, denie him, forsweare him, or else wee are all vndone.

div.stage: Exit Biondello, Tranio and Pedant as fast as may be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pardon sweete father. Kneele.

sp.speaker: Vin,
sp.l: Liues my sweete sonne?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Pardon deere father.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: How hast thou offended, where is Lucentio?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Heere's Lucentio right sonne to the right Vincentio,
That haue by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit supposes bleer'd thine eine.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Heere's packing with a witnesse to deceiue vs all.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Where is that damned villaine Tranio,
That fac'd and braued me in this matter so?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Why, tell me is not this my Cambio?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Cambio is chang'd into Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Loue wrought these miracles. Biancas loue
Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
While he did beare my countenance in the Towne,
And happilie I haue arriued at the last
Vnto the wished hauen of my blisse:
What Tranio did, my selfe enforst him to:
Then pardon him sweete Father for my sake.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ile slit the villaines nose that would haue sent me to the Iaile.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: But doe you heare sir, haue you married my daughter without asking my good will?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Feare not Baptista, wee will content you go to: but I will in to be reueng'd for this villanie. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: And I to sound the depth of this knauerie. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Looke not pale Bianca, thy father will not frowne.

sp.speaker: Gre,
sp.l: My cake is dough, but Ile in among the rest,
Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Husband let's follow, to see the end of this adoe.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: First kisse me Kate, and wee will.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: What in the midst of the streete?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What are thou asham'd of me?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: No sir, God forbid, but asham'd to kisse.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why then let's home againe: Come Sirralet's away.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Nay, I will giue thee a kisse, now pray Loue stay.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Is not this well? come my sweete Kate.
Better once then neuer, for neuer too late. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Baptista, Vincentio, Gremio, the Pedant, Lucentio, and Bianca, Tranio, Biondello Grumio, and widdow: The seruingmen with Tranio bringing in a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: At last though long, our iarring notes agree,
And time it is when raging warre is come,
To smile at scapes and perils ouerblowne:
My faire Bianca bid my father welcome,
While I with selfe same kindnesse welcome thine:
Brother Petruchio, sister Katerina,
And thou Hortensio with thy louing Widdow:
Feast with the best, and welcome to my house,
My banket is to close our stomakes vp
After our great good cheere: pray you sit downe,
For now wee sit to chat as well as eate.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nothing but sit and sit, and eate and eate.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Padua affoords this kindnesse sonne Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Padua affords nothing but what is kinde.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For both our sakes I would that word were true.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now for my life Hortensio feares his Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Then neuer trust me if I be affeard.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You are very sensible, and yet you misse my sence:
I meane Hortentio is afeard of you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: He that is giddie thinkes the world turns round.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Roundly replied.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Mistris how meane you that?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Thus I conceiue by him.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Conceiues by me, how likes Hortensio that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Widdow sayes, thus she conceiues her tale.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Verie well mended: kisse him for that good Widdow.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: He that is giddie thinkes the world turnes round,
I pray you tell me what you meant by that.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Your husband being troubled with a shrew,
Measures my husbands sorrow, by his woe:
And now you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: A verie meane meaning,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Right. I meane you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: And I am meane indeed, respecting you.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To her Kate.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To her Widdow.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That's my office

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Spoke like an Officer: ha to thee Lad.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: How likes Gremio these quicke witted folkes?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Beleeue me sir, they But together well.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Head, and But an hastie witted bodie,
Would say your Head and But were head and horne.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I Mistris Bride, hath that awakened you?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I, but not frighted me, therefore Ile sleepe againe,

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay that you shall not since you haue begun:
Haue at you for a better Iest or too.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Am I your Bird, I meane to shift my bush,
And then pursue me as you draw my Bow.
You are welcome all. Exit Bianca.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: She hath preuented me, here signior Tranio,
This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not,
Therfore a health to all that shot and mist.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Oh sir, Lucentio slipt me like his Gray-hound,
Which runs himselfe and catches for his Master.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A good swift simile, but something currish.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Tis well sir that you hunted for your selfe:
'Tis thought your Deere does hold you at a baye.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Oh, oh Pretuchio, Tranio hits you now.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I thanke thee for that gird good Tranio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Confesse, confesse, hath he not hit you here?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A has a litle gald me I confesse:
And as the Iest did glaunce away from me,
'Tis ten to one it maim'd you too out right.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now in good sadnesse sonne Petruchio,
I thinke thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Well I say no: and therefore sir, assurance,
Let's each one send vnto his wife,
And he whose wife is most obedient,
To come at first when he doth send for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propose.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Content what's the wager?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Twentie crownes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Twentie crownes.
Ile venture so much of my Hawke or Hound,
But twentie times so much vpon my Wife.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A hundred then.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A match 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Who shall begin?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That will I.
Goe Biondello, bid your Mistris come to me.

sp.speaker: Bio.
sp.l: I goe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Sonne Ile be your halfe, Bianca comes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ile haue no halues: Ile beare it all my selfe.
How now, what newes?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Sir, my Mistris sends you word
That she is busie, and shee cannot come.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How? she's busie and shee cannot come: is that an answere?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: I, and a kinde one too:
Praie God sir your wife send you not a worse.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I hope better.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Sirra Biondello, goe and intreate my wife to come to mee forthwith. Exit. Bion.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Oh ho intreate her, nay then she must needes come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am affraid sir, doe what you can
Yours will not be intreated: Now where's my wife?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: She sayes you haue some goodly Iest in hand,
She will not come: she bids you come to her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Worse and worse she will not come:
Oh vild, intollerable, not to be indur'd:
Sirra Grumio, goe to your Mistris,
Say I command her come to me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know her answere.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She will not.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now by my hollidam here comes Katerina.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: What is your will sir, that you send for me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Where is your sister, and Hortensios wife?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: They sit conferring by the Parler fire.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Goe fetch them hither, if they denie to come,
Swinge me them foundly forth vnto their husbands:
Away I say, and bring them hither straight.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here is a wonder, if you talke of a wonder.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And so it is: I wonder what it boads

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Marrie peace it boads, and loue, and quiet life,
An awfull rule, and right supremacie:
And to be short, what not, that's sweete and happie.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now faire befall thee good Petruchio;
The wager thou hast won, and I will adde
Vnto their losses twentie thousand crownes,
Another dowrie to another daughter,
For she is chang'd as she had neuer bin.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay, I will win my wager better yet,
And shew more signe of her obedience,
Her new built vertue and obedience.
See where she comes, and brings your froward Wiues
As prisoners to her womanlie perswasion:
Katerine, that Cap of yours becomes you not,
Off with that bable, throw it vnder foote.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Lord let me neuer haue a cause to sigh,
Till I be brought to such a sillie passe.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Fie what a foolish dutie call you this?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I would your dutie were as foolish too:
The wisdome of your dutie faire Bianca,
Hath cost me fiue hundred crownes since supper time,

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: The more foole you for laying on my dutie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Katherine I charge thee tell these head-strong women, what dutie they doe owe their Lords and husbands.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Come, come, your mocking: we will haue no telling.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come on I say, and first begin with her,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: She shall not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say she shall, and first begin with her.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Fie, fie, vnknit that threatning vnkind brow,
And dart not scornefull glances from those eies,
To wound thy Lord, thy King, thy Gouernour.
It blots thy beautie, as frosts doe bite the Meades,
Confounds thy fame, as whirlewindes shake faire budds,
And in no sence is meete or amiable.
A woman mou'd, is like a fountaine troubled,
Maddie, ill seeming thicke, bereft of beautie,
And while it is so, none so drie or thirstie
Will daigne to sip or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy Lord▪ thy life, thy Keeper,
Thy head, thy soueraigne: one that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance: Commits his bodie
To painfull labour, both by sea and land:
To watch the night in stormes, the day in cold,
Whi'st thou ly'st warme at home, secure and safe,
And craues no other tribute at thy hands,
But loue, fare lookes, and true obedience;
Too litle payment for so great a debt.
Such dutie as the subiect owes the Prince,
Euen such a woman oweth to her husband:
And when she is froward, peeuish, sullen, sower,
And not obedient to his honest will:
What is she but a foule contending Rebell,
And gracelesse Traitour to her louing Lord?
I am a sham'd that women are so simple,
To offer warre, where they should kneele for peace:
Or seeke for rule, supremacie, and sway,
When they are bound to serue, loue, and obay.
Why are our bodies soft, and weake, and smooth,
Vnapt to toyle, and trouble in the world,
But that our soft conditions, and our harts.
Should well agree with our externall parts?
Come, come, you froward and vnable wormes
My minde hath bin as bigge as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reason haplie more,
To bandie word for word, and frowne for frowne;
But now I see our Launces are but strawes:
Our strength as weake, our weakenesse past compare,
That seeming to be most, which we indeed least are.
Then vale your stomackes, for it is no boote,
And place your hands below your husbands foote:
In token of which dutie, if he please,
My hand is readie may it do him ease.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why ther's a wench: come on, and kisse me Kate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Well go thy wayes old Lad for thou shalt ha't.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing, when children are toward.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But a harsh hearing, when women are froward,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come Kate, wee'l to bed,
We three are married, but you two are sped.
'Twas I won the wager though you hit the white.
And being a winner, God giue you good night,

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Now go thy wayes thou hast tam'd a curst Shrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis a wonder by your leaue, she will tam'd so.
